questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Silicosis:

  • In its early stages shows tiny, barely palpable, discrete pale to blackened nodules in the hilar lymph nodes and upper zones of the lungs.
  • With time, via lymphatics, fibrosis and calcification occur in hilar lymph nodes, giving a typical X Ray appearance of Eggshell calcifications.
  • The hallmark histology feature is a silicotic collagenous nodule.

Mesothelioma:

  • Prolonged asbestos exposure can result in mesothelioma, which is a peripheral tumour of the lungs arising from the pleura.
  • These tumours show malignant pleural effusion without mediastinal shift.

Caplan syndrome:

  • It is a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis.
  • Commonly seen with silicosis and coal workers' pneumoconiosis.
  • Manifests as intrapulmonary rheumatoid nodules.
  • The nodules appear as well-defined and homogenous on chest x-ray and show necrobiotic granulomas in histology.

Asbestosis:

  • It manifests as interstitial fibrosis, which is more severe in the lower zones of the lung.
  • Pleural plaques, the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure, are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen that are often calcified.
  • Pleural plaques develop most frequently on the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and over the domes of the diaphragm.
  • Asbestos bodies and ferruginous bodies are typically seen in the histopathology of asbestosis.

    Fig: Asbestosis-related pleural plaques

questions.text: A gross specimen of the lung is shown below. Based on your findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The gross specimen of lungs shows numerous small nodules distributed uniformly throughout the lungs, classically described as millet-like granules. This is typically seen in miliary tuberculosis.

  • Miliary tuberculosis can occur when TB lung lesions erode pulmonary veins or when extrapulmonary TB lesions erode systemic veins.
  • This results in hematogenous dissemination of tubercle bacilli, producing myriads of 1-2 mm lesions throughout the body in susceptible hosts.
  • Miliary spread limited to the lungs can occur following erosion of pulmonary arteries by TB lung lesions.
  • Grossly, this is a miliary pattern of granulomas because there are a multitude of small tan granulomas about 2-4 mm in size, scattered throughout the lung parenchyma.
  • The miliary pattern gets its name from the resemblance of the granulomas to millet seeds.

Explanation of other options:

Pneumoconiosis (Option B): Pneumoconiosis typically causes fibrosis, and gross features show firm fibrosed parenchyma.

Bronchiectasis (Option C): Characteristically, the bronchi and bronchioles are so dilated that they can be followed almost to the pleural surfaces. On the cut surface of the lung, the dilated bronchi appear cystic and are filled with mucopurulent secretions.

Pneumonia (Option D): Pneumonia is an acute inflammatory condition, with varying stages of infection and will show areas of consolidation.

questions.text: A middle-aged immunocompromised male presents with fever and breathlessness. HRCT showed a middle lobe lesion with infiltration in the lung. The histopathology of the lesion is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Histopathology shows a typical owl's eye appearance, characteristic of cytomegalovirus. CMV infections mostly affect immunocompromised individuals.

  • Cytomegalovirus infection is characterised by enlargement of the infected cell & prominent intranuclear inclusion and perinuclear halo (Owl's eye appearance).
  • Infects the immunocompromised, and once infected, individuals carry CMV for their whole life.
  • Commonly causes interstitial pneumonia.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): Tuberculosis of the lungs is characterised by well-defined epithelioid cell granulomas.

Cryptogenic organising pneumonia (Option B): Also known as bronchiolitis obliterans organising pneumonia. It is a disease of unknown aetiology characterised by polypoid plugs of loose organising connective tissue (Masson bodies) within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and often bronchioles. The connective tissue is of the same age, with normal lung architecture and without interstitial fibrosis or honeycomb lung.

Small cell carcinoma (Option C): Small cell carcinoma shows small cells with scanty cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), with absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells can be round, oval, or spindle-shaped, with prominent nuclear moulding.

questions.text: A patient with a history of long-standing depressive illness was brought to the emergency department with acute breathlessness. The chest X-ray showed diffuse infiltrates with predominance in the right middle lobe and right lower lobe. However, despite intensive care patient expired and given below is the histopathology image of the lung obtained from the autopsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical setting of depressive illness suggests possible altered consciousness, thus a risk factor for aspiration. Histology shows foreign material embedded in the alveoli, surrounded by an inflammatory response, classic for aspiration pneumonia.

Aspiration pneumonia:

  • Aspiration is commonly seen in the elderly, debilitated
  • The resultant pneumonia is partly chemical due to the irritating effects of gastric acid and partly bacterial (from the oral flora).
  • Typically, culture shows more than one organism, aerobes being more common than anaerobes.
  • This type of pneumonia is often necrotising, pursues a fulminant clinical course, and is a frequent cause of death.
  • In patients who survive, lung abscess is a common complication.

Explanation of other options:

Severe fungal pneumonia (Option A): Fungal pneumonias are commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, and histology will show fungal hyphae.

Pulmonary tuberculosis (Option B): A striking radiology feature in pulmonary TB is the presence of a cavity, and histology shows ceasing granulomas surrounded by epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells.

Severe necrotising pneumonia (Option D): Many anaerobic organisms are normal commensals of the oral cavity, especially in people with poor dental hygiene. These include certain streptococci, fusobacteria and Bacteroides. Swallowing disorders, as in stuporous alcoholics, anaesthetised patients and people subject to seizures, predispose to aspirating anaerobic bacteria. Resulting pulmonary infections cause necrotising pneumonias, which often lead to lung abscesses. The most dramatic complication is gangrene of the lung.

questions.text: The histopathological section from a lesion excised from the right cervical region is shown below. Based on the findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Histopathology shows a central area of necrosis surrounded by epithelioid cells and giant cells characteristic of necrotising granulomatous inflammation commonly seen in tuberculosis.

  • Caseous necrosis is encountered most often in foci of tuberculous infection.
  • The term caseous (cheeselike) is derived from the friable white appearance of the area of necrosis.
  • On microscopic examination, the necrotic area appears as a structureless collection of fragmented or lysed cells and amorphous granular debris enclosed within a distinctive inflammatory border; this appearance is characteristic of a focus of inflammation known as a granuloma.

Explanation of other options:

Sarcoidosis (Option B): Sarcoidosis is a chronic granulomatous inflammatory condition. Involved tissues contain well-formed non-necrotising granulomas, composed of aggregates of tightly clustered epithelioid macrophages, often with giant cells. Central necrosis is unusual.

Fig: Noncaseating sarcoidal granulomas (asterisks), with many multinucleated giant cells (arrowheads).

Schwannoma (Option C): These are benign tumours that arise directly from peripheral nerves. Microscopically, they are an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively. The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is common. Resulting structures with central nuclear-free zones ramified by palisading nuclei are termed Verocay bodies. In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas, the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

Hodgkin lymphoma (Option D): The diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma depends on the identification of Reed-Sternberg cells in a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells. There is no associated necrosis or granulomas.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a history of dyspnea and productive cough. Despite intensive care, he died of respiratory failure. A gross image of the lung from the autopsy is shown below. What is the likely aetiology of his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The gross specimen of the lung shows dilated air spaces with surrounding normal lung parenchyma, hence the diagnosis of centriacinar emphysema, which is strongly associated with smoking.

Pathogenesis of Emphysema:


Explanation of other options:

Mutation in dynein arms (Option A): Dynein is a ciliary motor protein, mutation of which results in primary ciliary dyskinesia (immotile cilia syndrome). Defective mucociliary clearance can result in recurrent infections that lead to bronchiectasis. This is a genetic disorder caused by mutations affecting the dynein arms of cilia, which are essential for ciliary motility.

Antibodies against type IV collagen (Option D): Circulating autoantibodies against the non-collagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV cause Goodpasture syndrome. Both kidneys and the lungs are affected in this condition.

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in viral pneumonia EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Predominant alveolar exudate is a hallmark feature of bacterial pneumonia and not viral pneumonia.

  • The most common causes of community-acquired viral pneumonias are:
    • Influenza types A and B
    • Respiratory syncytial virus
    • Human metapneumovirus
    • Adenovirus
    • Rhinoviruses
    • Rubella virus
    • Varicella virus.
  • These pathogenic viruses share a propensity to infect and damage the respiratory epithelium, producing an inflammatory response.
  • Viral pneumonias are usually mild and resolve spontaneously without any lasting sequelae.
  • Clinical features: Fever, headache, and myalgia. Cough may be absent. 

Histology:

  • The predominant histologic pattern is an interstitial inflammatory reaction involving the walls of the alveoli. (Option A ruled out)
  • The alveolar septa are widened and edematous and usually contain a mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells.
  • The alveoli may be free of exudate, but in many patients, there is intra-alveolar proteinaceous material and a cellular exudate.
  • Some viruses, such as herpes simplex, varicella, and adenovirus, may be associated with necrosis of bronchial and alveolar epithelium causing (Option B ruled out).
  • Measles infection involves both the airways and the parenchyma. It is characterised by very large multinucleated giant cells with nuclear inclusions and large eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions. (Option C ruled out).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common outcome of Lobar pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common outcome of lobar pneumonia is resolution.

Outcomes of pneumonia include:

  • Resolution: In the final stage of resolution, the exudate within the alveolar spaces is broken down by enzymatic digestion to produce granular, semifluid debris that is resorbed, ingested by macrophages, expectorated, or organised by fibroblasts growing into it.
  • Organisation: In approximately 3% of cases, resolution of the exudate does not occur, but instead undergoes organisation, resulting in post-pneumonic fibrosis called carnification. (Option A ruled out)
  • Tissue destruction and necrosis, causing abscess formation. (Option D ruled out)
  • Spread of infection to the pleural cavity, causing an intrapleural fibrinosuppurative reaction known as (Option C ruled out)
  • Bacteremic dissemination to the heart valves, pericardium, brain, kidneys, spleen, or joints, causing abscesses, endocarditis, meningitis, or suppurative arthritis.

questions.text: Which among the following pathogens is associated with cotton candy exudates on histopathology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cotton candy alveolar exudates are characteristic of Pneumocystis pneumoniae.

  • Pneumocystis jiroveci is an opportunistic fungal pulmonary pathogen.
  • Characteristically causes interstitial pneumonia.
  • CXR shows bilateral diffuse peri-hilar infiltrates.
  • Pathogenesis
    • Attacks type I cells and damages them.
    • Hypertrophy of type II cells is seen, causing surfactant abnormalities.

Histology of Pneumocystis jiroveci infection

  • The involved areas of the lung contain a characteristic intraalveolar foamy, pink-staining exudate with hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) stain (cotton candy exudate).
  • Silver stain of tissue sections reveals round-to-cup-shaped cysts (4 to 10 µm in diameter) within the alveolar exudates; ping-pong ball appearance or cup & saucer arrangement.

    Fig: Silver staining of Pneumocystis jiroveci

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): Staphylococcal pneumonia is associated with a high incidence of complications, such as lung abscess and empyema. Intravenous drug users are at high risk for the development of staphylococcal pneumonia in association with endocarditis.

Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option B): Klebsiella pneumoniae is the most frequent cause of gram-negative bacterial pneumonia. It commonly afflicts debilitated and malnourished people, particularly chronic alcoholics. Thick, mucoid sputum is characteristic because the organism produces an abundant viscid capsular polysaccharide.

Moraxella catarrhalis (Option C): Moraxella catarrhalis is recognised as a cause of bacterial pneumonia, especially in the elderly. It is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of TB presents with fever, cough and hemoptysis. CT scan showed a mass in a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe. A lung biopsy was performed, and the Gomori methenamine-silver stain of the specimen is shown below. Based on the morphology, which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image shows fungal hyphae branching at acute angles, which is characteristic of Aspergillus. In a patient with prior tuberculosis and a mass within a pre-existing lung cavity, aspergilloma is to be suspected.

  • Aspergillus appears as a septate fungus with acute-angle branching dichotomous branching.
  • The fungus can be visualised with PAS and silver stain.
  • Aspergillus can cause various lung infections depending on the host's immune status. These are:

Aspergilloma:

  • Aspergilloma refers to the growth of the fungus in the respiratory tract with minimal or no invasion of the tissues.
  • Colonised lung cavities are usually the result of prior tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, old infarcts, or abscesses.
  • Proliferating masses of hyphae within proteinaceous debris form brownish fungus balls within the cavities.

Invasive aspergillosis:

  • Invasive aspergillosis is an opportunistic infection that is confined to immunosuppressed hosts.
  • The primary lesions are usually in the lung, but widespread hematogenous dissemination with involvement of the heart valves and brain is common.
  • The pulmonary lesions take the form of necrotising pneumonia.

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis:

  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis occurs in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis and frequently leads to bronchiectasis.
  • It is a hyperimmune response to the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus.

Explanation of other options:

Candida (Option B): Candida infections of the lungs are uncommon. Histologically, Candida appears as a budding yeast with pseudohyphae.

Cryptococcosis (Option C): Cryptococcosis in the lung may present as diffuse disease or focal consolidation. Due to its thick polysaccharide capsule, Cryptococcus neoformans appears as clear soap-bubble spaces on H&E stain. PAS and GMS highlight the yeast but not the capsule, creating a halo appearance. The mucicarmine stain specifically highlights the capsule.

Mucormycosis: (Option D): Pulmonary mucormycosis manifests as progressive fever with pneumonia. Under microscopy, mucormycetes appear broad, ribbon-like, with non-septate hyphae that branch at right angles.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not typically associated with atypical pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Staphylococcus aureus produces typical pneumonia, either lobar or bronchopneumonia.

  • Staphylococcus aureus is an important cause of secondary bacterial pneumonia in children and healthy adults following viral respiratory illnesses (e.g., measles in children and influenza in both children and adults).
  • Staphylococcal pneumonia is associated with a high incidence of complications, such as lung abscess and empyema.
  • Intravenous drug users are at high risk for the development of staphylococcal pneumonia in association with endocarditis.

Atypical pneumonia:

  • Atypical pneumonia begins insidiously, and respiratory symptoms may be minimal or severe.
  • Leukocytosis is absent or slight, and the course is prolonged.
  • Chest X-ray shows patchy intra-alveolar pneumonia or interstitial infiltrates.
  • Causative agents of atypical pneumonia:
    • Mycoplasma
    • Chlamydia
    • Influenza
    • Adenovirus
    • RSV
    • Legionella
    • Coxiella burnetii
    • Pneumocystis carinii.

questions.text: Which of the following is an infraclavicular lesion of post-primary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In post-primary tuberculosis, Assmann's focus is on the characteristic lesion found in the infraclavicular region.

  • Assman's focus represents an area of caseating consolidation, seen associated with post-primary TB.
  • Often seen in the apical segments of the upper lobes or the superior segments of the lower lobes.
  • It is usually less than 2 cm in diameter, within 1 to 2 cm of the apical pleura.
  • Such foci are sharply circumscribed, firm and gray-white to yellow.
  • Have variable degrees of central caseation and peripheral fibrosis.

Explanation of other options:

Gohn's focus (Option A): The lung lesion of primary tuberculosis is known as a Ghon focus. It is found in the subpleural area of the upper segments of the lower lobes or the lower segments of the upper lobes. Initially, it is a small, ill-defined area of inflammatory consolidation, which then drains to the hilar lymph nodes. The combination of a peripheral Ghon focus and involved mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes is called the Ghon complex.

Puhl's focus (Option B): Aschoff Puhl's lesion is the term for an isolated lesion of chronic pulmonary TB in the apex of the lung. It is characterised by coarse granular dissemination.

Simmon's focus (Option D): Hematogenous spread to the apex of the upper lobe results in a post-primary infective lesion, which heals with scarring and is known as Simon's focus. The lesion is subpleural and appears as a fibronodular patch or ill-defined reticular shadow in the upper lung fields on chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a previous history of tuberculosis presents with cough, weight loss, and night sweats. Reactivation of TB is suspected. Which part of the lung is most commonly affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Secondary pulmonary tuberculosis is classically localised to the apex of one or both upper lobes.

  • The lung apex has higher oxygen tension, which favours the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, an obligate aerobe.
  • Hence, secondary TB more often occurs in the lung apex.
  • Because of the preexistence of hypersensitivity, the bacilli elicit a prompt tissue response that tends to wall off the focus.
  • Primary tuberculosis tends to occur more often subpleurally. (Option D ruled out)
  • The lung bases are less commonly involved in reactivation TB due to their lower oxygen tension. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in primary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cavitatory lesions are unlikely in primary tuberculosis and are commonly seen in TB reactivation.

Primary tuberculosis

  • A form of disease that develops in a previously unexposed and therefore unsensitized patient.
  • Features of primary tuberculosis:
    • Ghon focus
    • Ghon complex
    • Ranke complex: Formed by fibrosis and calcification of Gohn's complex. (Option C ruled out)

Secondary tuberculosis

  • Pattern of disease that arises in a previously sensitised host. Commonly arises from reactivation of the dormant primary lesion.
  • Features of secondary tuberculosis:
    • Cavitation - Due to necrosis and liquefaction of primary lesions
    • Simmon'somplex
    • Assman focus
    • Aschof-puhl complex

Both primary and secondary tuberculosis are characterised histologically by caseating granulomas composed of central necrosis surrounded by epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells. (Option B, D ruled out)

questions.text: The following image shows structures found in the sputum of a patient with bronchial asthma. What is the major component of these structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image above shows Charcot-Leyden crystals, which are commonly found in the sputum of asthmatic patients. They are made of eosinophil protein galectin-10.

Microscopic findings of sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimens of asthmatic patients:

  • Curschmann spirals: Result from the extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles.
  • Numerous eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals are composed of the eosinophil-derived protein galectin-10.
  • Creola bodies - These are desquamated ciliated columnar epithelium.

Fig: A) Curschmann spirals; B) Charcot-Leyden crystals with trichome stain; C) Creola bodies

Explanation of other options:

Mast cell granule (Option A): Mast cell granules contain inflammatory mediators like histamine, tryptase, and prostaglandins, which are released upon activation. However, they do not produce Galectin-10 Epithelial debris.

Epithelial debris (Option B): These are sloughed-off epithelial cells, which may be seen in sputum due to chronic airway irritation and are not specific to asthma.

Asbestos fibres (Option D): Asbestos fibres are found associated with asbestosis. Asbestos fibres are partially digested by macrophages and undergo deposition of iron and proteinaceous material around, forming asbestos bodies / Ferruginous bodies.

Fig: Ferruginous bodies stained by Perl's stain

Fig: Perl's prussian blue stain

Key Takeaways:

Microscopic sputum findings in asthmatics:

  • Curschmann spirals
  • Charcot-leyden crystals
  • Creola bodies

questions.text: A 15-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, and cough, especially at night. Laboratory tests reveal peripheral eosinophilia. Which immunoglobulin is primarily involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation is classic of bronchial asthma, which is a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE immunoglobulin.

Pathogenesis of asthma:

  • Inhaled allergens (antigens) elicit a Th2-dominated response favouring IgE production and eosinophil recruitment.
  • On re-exposure to the antigen, an immediate reaction is triggered by antigen-induced cross-linking of IgE bound to Fc receptors on mast cells.
  • These cells release preformed mediators that directly and via neuronal reflexes induce bronchospasm, increased vascular permeability, mucus production, and
  • recruitment of leukocytes.
  • Leukocytes recruited to the site of reaction release additional mediators that initiate the late-phase reaction.
  • Several factors released from eosinophils also cause damage to the epithelium.

Explanation of other options:

IgM (Option A): IgM antibodies are major serum immunoglobulins which play an important role in acute infections. They have no role in allergic responses.

IgD (Option C): These are found on the surface of immature B cells and act as receptors which help in B cell activation.

IgA (Option D): IgA antibodies are secretory immunoglobulins present in all secretions and play an important role in protecting mucous membranes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive dyspnea, minimal cough and weight loss. On examination, his symptoms and signs are consistent with those of pink puffers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pink puffer is a term used to describe patients with emphysema-predominant COPD.

  • Classically, the patient is barrel-chested and dyspneic, with obviously prolonged expiration, sits forward in a hunched-over position, and breathes through pursed lips.
  • Cough is often slight, overdistention of the lungs is severe, diffusion capacity is low, and blood gas values are relatively normal at rest.
  • Since they maintain relatively good oxygenation (pink) and use pursed-lip breathing to ease exhalation (puffer), they are called pink puffers.
  • Weight loss is common and can be so severe as to suggest an occult cancer.

Explanation of other options:

Chronic bronchitis (Option A): Patients with pure chronic bronchitis are referred to as blue bloaters. Their cardinal symptom is a persistent cough with sputum, coupled with hypercapnia, hypoxemia, and mild cyanosis.

Bronchiectasis (Option B): Bronchiectasis causes a severe, persistent cough with expectoration of foul-smelling smelling. Symptoms are often episodic, and paroxysms of cough are particularly frequent when the patient rises in the morning, as the change in position causes collections of pus and secretions to drain into the bronchi.

Asthma (Option C): Asthmatic patients present with wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough, which vary over time and in intensity. Symptomatic episodes are most likely to occur at night or in the early morning. In atopic asthma, features like allergic shiners, mouth breathing, nasal crease, and atopic dermatitis may be seen.

Key Takeaways:

  • Blue blotters - Chronic bronchitis
  • Pink puffers - Emphysema

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of heavy smoking presents with exertional dyspnea and a chronic dry cough that has worsened over several years. Lung biopsy showed diffuse accumulation of finely pigmented macrophages filling the alveolar spaces. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation described and histology findings of a large number of macrophages filling airspaces are characteristic of desquamative interstitial pneumonitis.

Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis

  • Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis is a form of restrictive lung disease seen in cigarette smokers.
  • Desquamative interstitial pneumonia usually presents in the fourth or fifth decade of life.
  • Presenting symptoms include an insidious onset of dyspnea and dry cough over weeks or months, often associated with clubbing of digits.
  • Interstitial fibrosis, when present, is mild. Emphysema is often present.
  • Pulmonary function tests usually show a mild restrictive abnormality and moderately decreased diffusing capacity.

Histology findings

  • The most striking finding is the accumulation of a large number of macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment (smokers’ macrophages) in the airspaces.
  • The alveolar septa are thickened by a sparse inflammatory infiltrate of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and occasional eosinophils.

Explanation of other options:

Respiratory bronchiolitis-interstitial lung disease (Option A): Respiratory bronchiolitis with interstitial lung disease occurs under a similar clinical scenario (i.e., a tobacco user presenting with dyspnea on exertion and chronic cough), but has patchy involvement of the pulmonary parenchyma and not diffuse involvement.

Chronic silicosis (Option B): In chronic silicosis, the aetiology is silica exposure and not smoking. Also, histology will show characteristic silicotic collagenous nodules.

Chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Option C): Chronic disease is characterised by insidious onset of cough, dyspnea, malaise, and weight loss. Interstitial fibrosis with fibroblastic foci, honeycombing, and obliterative bronchiolitis, together with granulomas, are histology findings in the chronic phase.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female was evaluated for chronic cough and exertional dyspnea on exertion, which developed over a few years. A lung biopsy revealed areas of honeycomb changes, fibroblastic foci, and areas of normal lung parenchyma interspersed with fibrosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The biopsy showing alternating areas of patchy interstitial fibrosis, fibroblastic foci, honeycombing, and areas of normal lung reflects temporal and spatial heterogeneity, which is a hallmark finding of usual interstitial pneumonitis.

  • The histologic pattern present on biopsy of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is termed usual interstitial pneumonitis. It's a form of restrictive lung disease, which begins insidiously, with the gradual onset of dyspnea on exertion and dry cough, usually for 1-3 years.
  • The characteristic histologic features are temporally heterogeneous changes, honeycomb change, and fibroblastic foci, and areas of unaffected lung interspersed between areas of affected lung (i.e., patchy distribution).
  • In autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and systemic sclerosis, pulmonary involvement shows histologic patterns of usual interstitial pneumonitis.

Explanation of other options:

Sarcoidosis (Option B): Multisystem, chronic granulomatous inflammatory disorder of unknown aetiology. Histology will show non-caseating granulomas, which are not seen with interstitial pneumonitis.

Acute interstitial pneumonia (Option C): It's an acute inflammatory condition, where the patient develops ARDS. As ARDS progresses, dyspnea worsens, and the patient becomes cyanotic. Histology shows diffuse alveolar damage with hyaline membrane, interstitial and alveolar oedema.

Nonspecific interstitial pneumonitis (Option D): In NSIP, shortness of breath and cough develop over months to years. NSIP is temporally homogenous, and the pulmonary parenchyma shows diffuse and uniform changes. Honeycombing and fibroblastic foci are inconspicuous or absent.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a chronic non-productive cough, shortness of breath and a history of uveitis. A lung biopsy revealed non-caseating granulomas with asteroid bodies. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of the above respiratory symptoms with uveitis and histology features non-caseating granulomas and asteroid bodies suggests a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

  • Sarcoidosis is a multisystem chronic granulomatous inflammatory disorder of unknown aetiology.
  • Sarcoidosis can cause interstitial fibrosis, leading to a restrictive lung disease, which can present with chronic cough and shortness of breath.

Extra-pulmonary manifestations:

  • Uveitis
  • Parotitis
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Raised serum calcium

Histology features:

  • Non-caseating granulomas with the giant cells containing asteroid bodies and Schaumann's bodies.
  • Concentric lamellar fibrosis
  • Minimal interstitial fibrosis

Explanation of other options:

Acute interstitial pneumonia (Option A): It's an acute inflammatory condition, where the patient develops ARDS. As ARDS progresses, dyspnea worsens, and the patient becomes cyanotic. Histology shows diffuse alveolar damage with hyaline membrane, interstitial and alveolar oedema.

Usual interstitial pneumonitis (Option B): UIP also begins insidiously, with gradual onset of dyspnea on exertion and dry cough, usually for 1-3 years. But a lung biopsy will show alternating areas of patchy interstitial fibrosis, fibroblastic foci, honeycombing, and areas of normal lung, which is a hallmark finding of usual interstitial pneumonitis.

Chronic silicosis (Option D): The condition has a strong association with silica exposure. Though patients present with slow and insidious onset progressive dyspnea and dry cough, histology shows characteristic silicotic collagenous nodules.

questions.text: A lung biopsy from a 51-year-old man with chronic dyspnea reveals granulomas predominantly located in the alveolar septa, some associated with interstitial fibrosis. Special stains for acid-fast bacilli are negative. Which of the following is the most likely occupation associated with this lung pathology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The microscopic findings are suggestive of chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis, with Farmer's lung, caused by exposure to thermophilic Actinomyces, which stains negatively for acid-fast bacilli.

  • Farmer's lung results from exposure to dust generated from humid, warm, newly harvested hay that permits the rapid proliferation of the spores of thermophilic actinomycetes.
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis describes a spectrum of immunologically mediated, predominantly interstitial lung disorders caused by intense, often prolonged exposure to inhaled organic antigens like spores of bacteria, fungi, and animal proteins.

Diagnosis

  • Presence of IgG antibodies against the antigen detected by fluorescent enzyme immunoassay (FEIA)
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage specimens show increased numbers of CD4 and CD8 T lymphocytes.
  • Radiology findings:
    • Ground glass appearance of mid-zone, lower zone (due to alveolitis)
    • Reticulo-nodular shadows
    • Fibrosis
    • Honeycomb lung (due to traction caused by fibrosis)

Histology

  • Poorly formed non-caseating granuloma (Option A ruled out)
  • Multinucleated giant cells (Option C ruled out)
  • Granulomatous interstitial lung disease with lymphocytic infiltration (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Coal miner (Option B): Coal miners are at risk of developing coal workers' pneumoconiosis or anthracosis due to exposure to carbon. Lung biopsy will show coal macules with carbon-laden macrophages.

Railroad engineer (Option C): Railroad engineers are often at risk of asbestos exposure and can develop asbestosis with a high risk of mesothelioma and lung carcinoma. Microscopically, asbestosis is characterised by the presence of asbestos bodies, also known as ferruginous bodies.

Concrete pourer (Optithe on D): These individuals are at risk of inhaling silica and can develop silicosis, which shows silicotic collagenous nodules in a lung biopsy.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is being evaluated for symptoms of dyspnea, chronic cough, and raised erythematous skin lesions. Chest radiograph revealed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and a lung biopsy showed non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following organs is least commonly involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical presentation and findings are characteristic of sarcoidosis. In sarcoidosis, CNS involvement is very rare.

  • Although sarcoidosis can manifest in many different ways, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy or lung involvement (or both), visible on chest radiographs, is the major finding at presentation in most cases.
  • Eye and skin involvement each occurs in about 25% of cases, and either may occasionally be the presenting feature of the disease.

Manifestations

  • Lung: Interstitial lung disease
  • Skin: Erythema nodosum, lupus pernio
  • Uveitis
  • Parotitis
  • Raised serum calcium
  • Liver: Portal HTN, Cirrhosis

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of working in the shipyard was evaluated for his chronic respiratory symptoms. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with this exposure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Individuals working in shipyards are at risk of asbestos exposure, and arthralgia is not a symptom associated with asbestos exposure.

Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Localised fibrous plaques, or, rarely, diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Pleural effusions (recurrent)
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Laryngeal, ovarian, and app. 512- 514 other extrapulmonary neoplasms, including colon carcinoma
  • Increased risks for systemic autoimmune diseases and cardiovascular disease

questions.text: A young lady presented with bilateral erythematous nodular skin lesions. On evaluation, chest X-ray revealed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and the Mantoux test showed an indurated area. Which of the following findings is not associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is consistent with sarcoidosis, which is characterised by non-caseating granulomas that lack central necrosis.

  • Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disease of unknown aetiology characterised by noncaseating granulomatous inflammation in many tissues and organs.
  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy or lung involvement (or both), visible on chest radiographs, is the major finding in most cases.
  • In sarcoidosis, the Mantoux test is often negative or shows minimal induration.

Characteristics of Sarcoid Granuloma:

  • Non-caseating epithelioid cell granulomas
  • Naked granulomas - absent or Non-caseatingocytic infiltration.
  • Concentric lamellar fibrosis
  • Granulomas may involve the submucosa of the bronchi with protrusions, a characteristic interstitial fibrosis
  • Multinucleated giant cells may contain characteristic inclusions:
    • Asteroid bodies - stellate eosinophilic inclusions.
    • Schaumann bodies - laminated, calcified bodies.
  • They follow broncho-vascular bundles and may extend to the pleura.
  • Granulomas show 1α-hydroxylase activity, which results in excess vitamin D, causing hypercalcemia and nephrolithiasis (calcium stones).

Diagnosis

  • Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) reveals a high CD4:CD8 ratio (> 10:)
  • Gallium 67 scintigraphy is used to find granuloma.
    • Lambda sign - uptake in bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes.
    • Panda sign - uptake in lacrimal, salivary, and parotid glands.
  • Raised Serum Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) levels.
  • Biopsy- Demonstrates granuloma in the submucosa of the bronchus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old farmer presents with progressive shortness of breath, dry cough, and fatigue. High-resolution CT of the chest revealed ground-glass opacities, and bronchoalveolar lavage showed lymphocytosis. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most commonly involved in the pathogenesis of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario describes hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which is a type III hypersensitivity reaction mediated by immune complex formation.

  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated inflammatory lung disease that primarily affects the alveoli and is therefore often called allergic alveolitis.
  • The hypersensitivity results from intense, often prolonged exposure to inhaled organic antigens. Spores of thermophilic bacteria, fungi, animal proteins, or bacterial products.

Pathogenesis:

  • In this condition, inhaled antigens stimulate IgG antibody production.
  • These antibodies bind to the inhaled antigen in the alveoli, forming antigen-antibody immune complexes.
  • These complexes activate complement, leading to inflammation, neutrophil recruitment, and tissue injury in the alveolar walls.

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of IgG antibodies against the antigen detected by fluorescent enzyme immunoassay (FEIA)
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage specimens show increased numbers of CD4 and CD8 T lymphocytes.
  • Radiology findings:
    • Ground glass appearance of mid-zone, lower zone (due to alveolitis)
    • Reticulo-nodular shadows
    • Fibrosis
    • Honeycomb lung (due to traction caused by fibrosis)

Explanation of other options:

Type I Hypersensitivity Reaction (Option A): These reactions are mediated by IgE antibodies and are seen in anaphylaxis, bronchial asthma and allergies.

Type II Hypersensitivity Reaction (Option B): This is an antibody-mediated hypersensitivity reaction and is typically seen in autoimmune hemolytic anaemia, Goodpasture syndrome.

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reaction (Option D): Also known as delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, and is mediated by activated T lymphocytes in conditions like tuberculosis, contact dermatitis, and type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presented with a chronic cough and hoarseness of voice. On evaluation, chest X-ray showed pleural effusion and a peripheral lung mass. A biopsy was performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and histology, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image shows malignant glandular structures, and since the patient presented with a peripheral lung mass, adenocarcinoma is most likely. The associated hoarseness of voice and pleural effusion suggest invasive behaviour of the tumour.

  • Adenocarcinomas are usually peripherally located, but may also occur closer to the hilum.
  • Adenocarcinoma has a precursor sequence: Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia (AAH) → adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) → adenocarcinoma.

Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia:

  • A small precursor lesion (≤5 mm) characterised by dysplastic pneumocytes lining alveolar walls that are mildly fibrotic.

Adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS):

  • The lesion will be less than 3 cm in size and is composed entirely of dysplastic cells growing along pre-existing alveolar septa.
  • The cells have more dysplasia than atypical adenomatous hyperplasia and may or may not have intracellular mucin.
  • Shows a lepidic pattern (butterfly sitting on a fence - columnar cells lining alveoli).
  • Usually asymptomatic or presents with persistent cough and weight loss, but no pleural effusion or hoarseness, since it is non-invasive. (Option B ruled out)

Adenocarcinoma:

  • These are invasive malignant epithelial tumours with glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumour cells.
  • Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns, including acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid.
  • Tumour can invade the pleural space, resulting in malignant pleural effusion or invade the mediastinum to compress the recurrent laryngeal nerve to cause hoarseness of voice.

Explanation of other options:

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option C): These carcinomas are closely correlated with a smoking history; they tend to arise centrally in major bronchi and eventually spread to local hilar nodes, but they disseminate outside the thorax later than do other histologic types. Microscopically, they show keratinisation.

Large cell carcinomas (Option D): Large cell carcinomas are undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumours that lack the cytologic features of neuroendocrine carcinoma and show no evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation. The cells typically have large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and moderate amounts of cytoplasm.

choices.text: Small neoplastic cells with a high nuclear to cytoplasm ratio

questions.text: A 63-year-old chronic smoker presents with fatigue, constipation, and recurrent abdominal pain. She also reports recent-onset seizures. Laboratory tests showed elevated serum calcium levels. Chest radiograph showed a mass in the left upper lobe near the hilum. Which of the following histopathological findings is most likely seen on biopsy of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A centrally located upper lobe lung mass in a patient with hypercalcemia suggests squamous cell carcinoma with paraneoplastic manifestation. Keratin pearls are hallmark histology findings in squamous cell carcinoma.

Squamous cell carcinoma:

  • These are the most common cancers associated with smoking.
  • They arise mostly in the central part of the lung.
  • Histologically, squamous cell carcinoma is characterised by the presence of keratinisation and/or intercellular bridges.
  • Keratinisation may take the form of squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Some of these tumours secrete hormones like parathormone-related protein and which cause paraneoplastic hypercalcemia.
  • Hypercalcemia is the most common paraneoplastic manifestation seen with SCC.

Explanation of other options:

Neoplastic glands (Option A): Neoplastic glandular structures are seen in adenocarcinoma, which commonly arise in the peripheral part of the lung. The most common paraneoplastic manifestation associated with adenocarcinoma is hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

Small neoplastic cells with a high nuclear to cytoplasm ratio (Option B): These are histology findings of small cell carcinoma. SIADH is the most common paraneoplastic manifestation seen with small-cell lung carcinoma.

Noncaseating granulomas (Option D): Noncaseating granulomas are classically seen in lung pathologies like sarcoidosis, berylliosis and hypersensitivity pneumonitis. None of these is associated with hypercalcemia.

questions.text:
Carcinoid tumours arise from which of the following cell types?
i. J cells
ii. Neuroectoderm
iii. Goblet cells
iv. Enterochromaffin cells
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carcinoid tumours arise from enterochromaffin cells, also known as the Kulchitsky cells.

  • Kulchitsky cells are neuroendocrine cells present in the respiratory and GI mucosa.
  • These cells tend to secrete hormones like serotonin, histamine, bradykinin, and prostaglandins. This secretion is usually stimulated by nerve endings.
  • These cells have somatostatin receptors. The hypothalamus produces somatostatin, which can stimulate these receptors and inhibit hormone secretion.
  • Kulchitsky cells can undergo hyperplasia, which can result in:
    • Tumorlet: A collection of these cells, usually less than 5mm in size.
    • Carcinoid: When the collection is more than five millimetres in size and localised.
    • Neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia: The term diffuse pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia (DIPNECH) is used, which often occurs in patients with COPD due to a trigger. This hyperplasia can progress to a tumorlet and then carcinoid.

Explanation of other options:

J cells (Option B): These are stretch receptors found in the pulmonary interstitium. They are involved in pulmonary reflexes and pathologies like congestion.

Neuroectoderm (Option C): Neuroectoderm gives rise to chromaffin cells, which secrete catecholamines in response to stress.

Goblet cells (Option D): Goblet cells are mucus-secreting epithelial cells of the respiratory and GIT mucosa. These do not give rise to carcinoid tumours.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a new-onset seizure. Laboratory investigations revealed a serum Na+ level of 128 mEq/L and urine osmolarity greater than serum osmolarity. Chest X-ray showed a central lung mass, and biopsy demonstrated tumour cells with salt and pepper chromatin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyponatremia with elevated urine osmolality indicates SIADH, a paraneoplastic syndrome commonly associated with small cell carcinoma. Diagnosis of small cell carcinoma is supported by both radiologic evidence and histologic findings.

Small Cell Lung Carcinoma:

  • Most common malignant neuroendocrine tumour of the lung.
  • Usually involves the central part of the lung (central bronchi).
  • Histology shows small, round, and blue cells and the characteristic Azzopardi effect and extensive necrosis.
  • Paraneoplastic Manifestations:
    • Associated with the maximum number of paraneoplastic manifestations.
    • The most common is Syndrome of Inappropriate ADH Secretion (SIADH).
    • Cushing syndrome is also a common endocrine manifestation.

Explanation of other options:

Adenocarcinoma (Option A): The most common paraneoplastic manifestation associated with adenocarcinoma is hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. These cancers commonly arise in the peripheral part of the lung, and histology will show glandular structures with mucin production.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option B): Squamous cell lung carcinomas also occur in the central part of the lung, but histology shows keratinisation and the most common paraneoplastic manifestation seen is hypercalcemia.

Mesothelioma (Option C): Mesothelioma is a malignant tumour of the pleura, thus a peripheral tumour. These are rarely associated with any paraneoplastic manifestations.

Key Takeaways:

Paraneoplastic manifestations of lung tumours:

  • Small cell carcinoma - SIADH
  • Adenocarcinoma - Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma - Hypercalcemia
